abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the outcome of the project is
            seen as satisfactory, with a sustainable likelihood, and
            substantial institutional development impacts, where both
            the Bank, and Borrower performances are rated satisfactory.
            Key lessons stress the effectiveness of a single-tranche
            operation in addressing specific issues, and providing
            limited budget support to the Government (in the context of
            a difficult policy dialogue), for it allowed time to build
            consensus on the reform agenda, while avoiding the
            requirements of conditionality-driven operations. Moreover,
            the effective timing of the project's financial
            assistance - tied to the budget cycle - provided
            compensatory financing for a reform program, as well as the
            availability of funds, for the Government's fiscal year
            2000 to be included in budgetary planning. Given the nature
            of adjustment lending, it is appropriate to focus on the
            Government's overall use of resources, rather than
            specific uses of Bank funds, which addresses the need for
            sound knowledge on the country's public financial
            management. The project was thus instrumental in preparing
            the analytical work, and in supporting policy reforms, and
            institutional changes needed to improve financial
            accountability, paving the way for the Country Procurement
            Assessment Report, and upcoming Country Financial
            Accountability Assessment. The long-term transition process,
            will benefit from this initial effort, particularly from the
            project's tax, and trade reform, which created an
            environment conducive to efficient private sector
            investment, and growth.
